questions.title: Introduction to the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS)
questions.question:
The GIPS standards were most likely developed for the benefit of:

  1. broker/dealers.
  2. prospective clients.
  3. middle-office operations.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. The GIPS standards benefit asset managers and their prospective clients and asset owners and their oversight bodies. Correct. The GIPS standards benefit asset managers and their prospective clients and asset owners and their oversight bodies. GIPS reports allow prospective clients to know that the track record of a GIPS-compliant firm is complete and fairly presented. Incorrect. Although the internal controls implemented improve middle-office operations, the GIPS standards were not developed with middle-office operations in mind. Introduction to the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS) explain why the GIPS standards were created, who can claim compliance, and who benefits from compliance
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. The GIPS standards benefit asset managers and their prospective clients and asset owners and their oversight bodies.

  2. Correct. The GIPS standards benefit asset managers and their prospective clients and asset owners and their oversight bodies. GIPS reports allow prospective clients to know that the track record of a GIPS-compliant firm is complete and fairly presented.

  3. Incorrect. Although the internal controls implemented improve middle-office operations, the GIPS standards were not developed with middle-office operations in mind.

questions.title: Introduction to the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS)
questions.question: A firm that does not adopt the GIPS standards could mischaracterize its overall performance by presenting a performance history:

choices.B: composed of a single top-performing portfolio.
choices.C: for an investment mandate over all periods since the firm’s inception.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. Selecting a top-performing portfolio to represent a firm’s overall investment results for a specific mandate, also known as using representative accounts, is a misleading practice that is not allowed under the GIPS standards. A is incorrect because including terminated portfolios is consistent with the GIPS standards. If the firm instead presented a performance history that excludes terminated portfolios, however, such a practice would be misleading and not allowed under the GIPS standards. C is incorrect because presenting performance for its mandate covering all periods since the firm’s inception is consistent with the GIPS standards. If the firm instead presented performance for a selected period during which it produced excellent returns or outperformed its benchmark, however, such a practice would be misleading and not allowed under the GIPS standards.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. Selecting a top-performing portfolio to represent a firm’s overall investment results for a specific mandate, also known as using representative accounts, is a misleading practice that is not allowed under the GIPS standards. A is incorrect because including terminated portfolios is consistent with the GIPS standards. If the firm instead presented a performance history that excludes terminated portfolios, however, such a practice would be misleading and not allowed under the GIPS standards. C is incorrect because presenting performance for its mandate covering all periods since the firm’s inception is consistent with the GIPS standards. If the firm instead presented performance for a selected period during which it produced excellent returns or outperformed its benchmark, however, such a practice would be misleading and not allowed under the GIPS standards.

questions.title: Introduction to the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS)
questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding GIPS compliance is correct?

choices.A: Asset owners that manage assets can claim compliance with the GIPS standards.
choices.B: Software that calculates performance in a manner consistent with the GIPS standards can claim compliance with the GIPS standards.
choices.C: Firms can comply with the GIPS standards by limiting their compliance claims to the provisions they have chosen to follow.

questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. Asset owners can claim compliance if they manage actual assets for which they are making a claim of compliance. B is incorrect because software (and the vendors that supply software) cannot be GIPS compliant. Software can assist firms in achieving compliance with the GIPS standards, but only a firm that manages actual assets can claim compliance. C is incorrect because a firm has only two options regarding compliance with the GIPS standards: fully comply with all applicable requirements of the GIPS standards and claim compliance through the use of the GIPS Compliance Statement; or not comply with all requirements of the GIPS standards and not claim compliance with, or make any reference to, the GIPS standards.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. Asset owners can claim compliance if they manage actual assets for which they are making a claim of compliance. B is incorrect because software (and the vendors that supply software) cannot be GIPS compliant. Software can assist firms in achieving compliance with the GIPS standards, but only a firm that manages actual assets can claim compliance. C is incorrect because a firm has only two options regarding compliance with the GIPS standards: fully comply with all applicable requirements of the GIPS standards and claim compliance through the use of the GIPS Compliance Statement; or not comply with all requirements of the GIPS standards and not claim compliance with, or make any reference to, the GIPS standards.

questions.title: Introduction to the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS)
questions.question:
Which of the following statements related to why the GIPS standards were created is least likely correct? The GIPS standards were created to:

  1. establish a standardized, industry-wide approach for investment firms to follow.
  2. provide clients certainty in what is presented and allow them to make reasonable comparisons.
  3. identify a set of ethical principles for firms to follow in calculating and presenting historical investment results.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. This is a correct statement. The GIPS standards were created to establish a standardized, industry-wide approach for investment firms to follow. Correct. The GIPS standards were created to ensure fair representation and full disclosure of investment performance, not to provide certainty in what is presented. Incorrect. This is a correct statement. The GIPS standards were created to identify a set of ethical principles for firms to follow in calculating and presenting historical investment results. Introduction to the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS) explain why the GIPS standards were created, who can claim compliance, and who benefits from compliance
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. This is a correct statement. The GIPS standards were created to establish a standardized, industry-wide approach for investment firms to follow.

  2. Correct. The GIPS standards were created to ensure fair representation and full disclosure of investment performance, not to provide certainty in what is presented.

  3. Incorrect. This is a correct statement. The GIPS standards were created to identify a set of ethical principles for firms to follow in calculating and presenting historical investment results.

questions.title: Introduction to the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS)
questions.question: Each composite of a GIPS-compliant firm must consist of:

choices.B: portfolios selected on an ex post basis.
choices.C: portfolios managed according to a similar investment mandate, objective, or strategy.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. A composite is an aggregation of one or more portfolios managed according to a similar investment mandate, objective, or strategy. For example, if a GIPS-compliant firm presents performance for a global equity composite (the composite), the composite must include portfolios that are managed, or have historically been managed, according to the firm’s global equity strategy. A is incorrect because a composite is an aggregation of one or more portfolios managed according to a similar investment mandate, objective, or strategy. A composite may consist of a single portfolio when it is the only portfolio managed according to a particular investment mandate. B is incorrect because the determination of which portfolio(s) to include in a composite should be done according to pre-established criteria ( ex ante basis), not after the fact ( ex post basis).
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. A composite is an aggregation of one or more portfolios managed according to a similar investment mandate, objective, or strategy. For example, if a GIPS-compliant firm presents performance for a global equity composite (the composite), the composite must include portfolios that are managed, or have historically been managed, according to the firm’s global equity strategy. A is incorrect because a composite is an aggregation of one or more portfolios managed according to a similar investment mandate, objective, or strategy. A composite may consist of a single portfolio when it is the only portfolio managed according to a particular investment mandate. B is incorrect because the determination of which portfolio(s) to include in a composite should be done according to pre-established criteria (ex ante basis), not after the fact (ex post basis).

questions.title: Introduction to the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS)
questions.question:
The GIPS standards were created to:

  1. promote fair, global competition among investment firms.
  2. eliminate the need for costly in-depth due diligence by investors.
  3. serve as a mandatory performance standard for asset management firms in countries without investment performance regulation.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct because the objectives of the GIPS standards are as follows: Promote fair, global competition among investment firms. Incorrect because the GIPS standards certainly do not eliminate the need for in-depth due diligence on the part of the client or investor, but compliance with the Standards enhances the credibility of investment management firms that have chosen to undertake this responsibility. Incorrect because complying with the GIPS standards is voluntary. Compliance with the GIPS standards is not typically required by legal or regulatory authorities. Also, the preamble to the GIPS standards states that by adhering to a global standard, firms in countries with minimal or no investment performance standards can compete for business on an equal footing with firms from countries with more-developed standards. Therefore, it is clear that GIPS standards were not created to serve as a mandatory performance standard for asset management firms in countries without investment performance regulation. Introduction to the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS) explain why the GIPS standards were created, who can claim compliance, and who benefits from compliance
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct because the objectives of the GIPS standards are as follows: Promote fair, global competition among investment firms.

  2. Incorrect because the GIPS standards certainly do not eliminate the need for in-depth due diligence on the part of the client or investor, but compliance with the Standards enhances the credibility of investment management firms that have chosen to undertake this responsibility.

  3. Incorrect because complying with the GIPS standards is voluntary. Compliance with the GIPS standards is not typically required by legal or regulatory authorities. Also, the preamble to the GIPS standards states that by adhering to a global standard, firms in countries with minimal or no investment performance standards can compete for business on an equal footing with firms from countries with more-developed standards.

    Therefore, it is clear that GIPS standards were not created to serve as a mandatory performance standard for asset management firms in countries without investment performance regulation.

questions.title: Introduction to the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS)
questions.question: Verification:

choices.A: must be performed on a firm-wide basis.
choices.B: may be provided by the firm’s compliance department.
choices.C: ensures the accuracy of a specific composite presentation.

questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. Verification is performed with respect to an entire firm, not on specific composites. B is incorrect because verification must be performed by an independent third party. C is incorrect because verification provides assurance on whether the firm’s policies and procedures related to composite and pooled fund maintenance, as well as the calculation, presentation, and distribution of performance, have been designed in compliance with the GIPS standards and have been implemented on a firm-wide basis; it does not ensure the accuracy of a specific composite presentation.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. Verification is performed with respect to an entire firm, not on specific composites. B is incorrect because verification must be performed by an independent third party. C is incorrect because verification provides assurance on whether the firm’s policies and procedures related to composite and pooled fund maintenance, as well as the calculation, presentation, and distribution of performance, have been designed in compliance with the GIPS standards and have been implemented on a firm-wide basis; it does not ensure the accuracy of a specific composite presentation.

questions.title: Introduction to the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS)
questions.question:
Which of the following can claim compliance with the GIPS standards?

  1. Consultants who advise investment firms that manage discretionary client assets
  2. Asset owners that do not compete for business but report their performance to oversight bodies
  3. Vendors that provide software to assist investment firms in claiming compliance with the GIPS standards
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because consultants cannot make a claim of compliance unless they actually manage the assets for which they are making a claim of compliance. They can claim to endorse the GIPS standards and/or require that their investment managers comply with the GIPS standards. Correct because asset owners may comply with the GIPS standards in the same way as firms if they compete for business. If they don’t compete for business but report their performance to an oversight body, asset owners may choose to comply with the GIPS Standards for Asset Owners. Incorrect because only a firm managing assets can claim compliance. Similarly, software (and the vendors who supply software) cannot be 'compliant.' Software can assist firms in achieving compliance with the GIPS standards (e.g., by calculating performance in a manner consistent with the calculation requirements of the GIPS standards), but only a firm managing assets can claim compliance once the firm has satisfied all applicable requirements of the GIPS standards. Introduction to the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS) explain why the GIPS standards were created, who can claim compliance, and who benefits from compliance
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because consultants cannot make a claim of compliance unless they actually manage the assets for which they are making a claim of compliance. They can claim to endorse the GIPS standards and/or require that their investment managers comply with the GIPS standards.

  2. Correct because asset owners may comply with the GIPS standards in the same way as firms if they compete for business. If they don’t compete for business but report their performance to an oversight body, asset owners may choose to comply with the GIPS Standards for Asset Owners.

  3. Incorrect because only a firm managing assets can claim compliance. Similarly, software (and the vendors who supply software) cannot be 'compliant.' Software can assist firms in achieving compliance with the GIPS standards (e.g., by calculating performance in a manner consistent with the calculation requirements of the GIPS standards), but only a firm managing assets can claim compliance once the firm has satisfied all applicable requirements of the GIPS standards.

questions.question:
Which of the following entities can claim compliance with the GIPS standards?

  1. A pension fund that manages investments for its beneficiaries
  2. An investment consulting firm that focuses on enabling clients to self-manage their investments
  3. A vendor that offers software products designed to help firms achieve compliance with the GIPS standards
questions.explanation: Solution Correct because according to the GIPS standards, only a firm managing assets can claim compliance once the firm has satisfied all applicable requirements of the GIPS standards. Further, asset owners may comply with the GIPS standards in the same way as firms if they compete for business. If they don’t compete for business but report their performance to an oversight body, asset owners may choose to comply with the GIPS Standards for Asset Owners. Therefore, a pension fund that manages investments for its beneficiaries can claim compliance with the GIPS standards. Incorrect because according to the GIPS standards, consultants cannot make a claim of compliance unless they actually manage the assets for which they are making a claim of compliance. Therefore, an investment consulting firm that focuses on enabling clients to self-manage their investments cannot claim compliance with the GIPS standards. Incorrect because according to the GIPS standards, software (and the vendors who supply software) cannot be “compliant.” Software can assist firms in achieving compliance with the GIPS standards (e.g., by calculating performance in a manner consistent with the calculation requirements of the GIPS standards), but only a firm managing assets can claim compliance once the firm has satisfied all applicable requirements of the GIPS standards. Introduction to the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS) explain why the GIPS standards were created, who can claim compliance, and who benefits from compliance
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct because according to the GIPS standards, only a firm managing assets can claim compliance once the firm has satisfied all applicable requirements of the GIPS standards. Further, asset owners may comply with the GIPS standards in the same way as firms if they compete for business. If they don’t compete for business but report their performance to an oversight body, asset owners may choose to comply with the GIPS Standards for Asset Owners. Therefore, a pension fund that manages investments for its beneficiaries can claim compliance with the GIPS standards.

  2. Incorrect because according to the GIPS standards, consultants cannot make a claim of compliance unless they actually manage the assets for which they are making a claim of compliance. Therefore, an investment consulting firm that focuses on enabling clients to self-manage their investments cannot claim compliance with the GIPS standards.

  3. Incorrect because according to the GIPS standards, software (and the vendors who supply software) cannot be “compliant.” Software can assist firms in achieving compliance with the GIPS standards (e.g., by calculating performance in a manner consistent with the calculation requirements of the GIPS standards), but only a firm managing assets can claim compliance once the firm has satisfied all applicable requirements of the GIPS standards.

questions.title: Introduction to the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS)
questions.question:
The GIPS standards most likely require:

  1. nondiscretionary segregated accounts to be included in composites.
  2. composites to be defined according to similar investment objectives or strategies.
  3. non–fee-paying segregated accounts to be excluded from the returns of appropriate composites.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. Composites must not include nondiscretionary segregated accounts. Correct. Composites must be defined according to similar investment objectives or strategies. Terminated segregated accounts must be included in the historical returns of appropriate composites, whereas only fee-paying segregated accounts are required to be included in composites. Nondiscretionary segregated accounts must not be included in a firm’s composites. Incorrect. Only fee-paying segregated accounts are required to be included in composites. questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. Composites must not include nondiscretionary segregated accounts.

  2. Correct. Composites must be defined according to similar investment objectives or strategies. Terminated segregated accounts must be included in the historical returns of appropriate composites, whereas only fee-paying segregated accounts are required to be included in composites. Nondiscretionary segregated accounts must not be included in a firm’s composites.

  3. Incorrect. Only fee-paying segregated accounts are required to be included in composites.

questions.title: Introduction to the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS)
questions.question:
Fundamental asset managers claim compliance with the CFA Institute Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS) and manage both discretionary and nondiscretionary segregated accounts. When constructing a single composite for the firm, Juma Dzuya includes all discretionary, fee-paying segregated accounts with both value and growth strategies. Does the composite constructed by Dzuya most likely meet GIPS criteria?

  1. Yes
  2. No, because of dissimilar investment strategies
  3. No, because nondiscretionary segregated accounts are not included
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. The composite is made up of portfolios with different mandates or strategies (e.g., growth and value). Correct. A composite must include all actual, fee-paying, discretionary portfolios managed in accordance with the same investment mandate, objective, or strategy. By including both the value and growth portfolios, the composite is made up of portfolios with different investment mandates or strategies. Incorrect. Nondiscretionary segregated accounts should not be included — that is, only discretionary segregated accounts should be included in composites to comply with the GIPS standards. Introduction to the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS) describe the key concepts of the GIPS Standards for Firms
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. The composite is made up of portfolios with different mandates or strategies (e.g., growth and value).

  2. Correct. A composite must include all actual, fee-paying, discretionary portfolios managed in accordance with the same investment mandate, objective, or strategy. By including both the value and growth portfolios, the composite is made up of portfolios with different investment mandates or strategies.

  3. Incorrect. Nondiscretionary segregated accounts should not be included — that is, only discretionary segregated accounts should be included in composites to comply with the GIPS standards.

questions.title: Introduction to the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS)
questions.question:
Performance that is not compliant with the GIPS standards is most likely allowed to be linked with performance that is compliant with the GIPS standards in which of the following scenarios?

  1. Wrap fee composite for a firm whose claim of compliance began on 1 January 2006.
  2. Real estate pooled fund for a firm whose claim of compliance began on 1 January 2010.
  3. Large-cap equity composite for a firm whose claim of compliance began on 1 January 2001.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct. The minimum effective compliance date for a wrap fee composite is 1 January 2006. A wrap fee composite for a firm whose claim of compliance began on 1 January 2006 could link performance that is not compliant with the GIPS standards to performance that is compliant with the GIPS standards. A firm may link performance that is not compliant with the GIPS standards to performance that is compliant with the GIPS standards provided that only performance that is compliant with the GIPS standards is presented for periods after the minimum effective compliance date, which differs depending on the asset type: 1 January 2006 for real estate and private equity composites and pooled funds, as well as wrap fee composites. 1 January 2000 for all other composites and pooled funds. Incorrect. The minimum effective compliance date for a real estate pooled fund is 1 January 2006. Incorrect. The minimum effective compliance date for all other composites and pooled funds is 1 January 2000. Introduction to the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS) describe the key concepts of the GIPS Standards for Firms
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct. The minimum effective compliance date for a wrap fee composite is 1 January 2006. A wrap fee composite for a firm whose claim of compliance began on 1 January 2006 could link performance that is not compliant with the GIPS standards to performance that is compliant with the GIPS standards. A firm may link performance that is not compliant with the GIPS standards to performance that is compliant with the GIPS standards provided that only performance that is compliant with the GIPS standards is presented for periods after the minimum effective compliance date, which differs depending on the asset type:

    • 1 January 2006 for real estate and private equity composites and pooled funds, as well as wrap fee composites.
    • 1 January 2000 for all other composites and pooled funds.

  2. Incorrect. The minimum effective compliance date for a real estate pooled fund is 1 January 2006.

  3. Incorrect. The minimum effective compliance date for all other composites and pooled funds is 1 January 2000.

To comply with the GIPS standards, firms most likely must:

questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because a firm must be defined as an investment firm, subsidiary, or division held out to clients or prospective clients as a distinct business entity. There is no requirement for the firm to be a separate legal entity.

  2. Correct because according to requirements for GIPS compliance, GIPS standards must be applied on a firm-wide basis. They cannot be separately applied to composites.

  3. Incorrect because firms are responsible for their own claims of compliance. Although a third-party independent verification is recommended, it is not required for compliance to be claimed by a firm.

questions.question:
When making performance presentations to prospective clients, a GIPS-compliant firm should least likely do which of the following?

questions.title: Introduction to the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS)
questions.question:
The GIPS standards:

  1. allow the use of a representative account to present the firm's overall investment results.
  2. require firms to present performance history that only includes accounts remaining at the firm.
  3. establish a standardized approach to presenting historical investment results to prospective clients.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because according to the GIPS standards misleading practices include Representative Accounts: Selecting a top-performing portfolio to represent the firm’s overall investment results for a specific mandate. Therefore, the GIPS standards does not allow the use of a representative account to present the firm's overall investment results. Incorrect because presenting an 'average' performance history that excludes portfolios whose poor performance was weak enough to result in termination of the firm is known as survivorship bias and is a misleading practice when presenting investment performance data. Therefore, presenting performance history that only includes accounts remaining at the firm (and excludes accounts that has left the firm) is incorrect. Correct because the GIPS standards are a practitioner-driven set of ethical principles that establish a standardized, industry-wide approach for investment firms to follow in calculating and presenting their historical investment results to prospective clients. Therefore, the GIPS standard establish a standardized approach to presenting historical investment results to prospective clients, and this answer is correct. Solution

  1. Incorrect because according to the GIPS standards misleading practices include Representative Accounts: Selecting a top-performing portfolio to represent the firm’s overall investment results for a specific mandate. Therefore, the GIPS standards does not allow the use of a representative account to present the firm's overall investment results.

  2. Incorrect because presenting an 'average' performance history that excludes portfolios whose poor performance was weak enough to result in termination of the firm is known as survivorship bias and is a misleading practice when presenting investment performance data. Therefore, presenting performance history that only includes accounts remaining at the firm (and excludes accounts that has left the firm) is incorrect.

  3. Correct because the GIPS standards are a practitioner-driven set of ethical principles that establish a standardized, industry-wide approach for investment firms to follow in calculating and presenting their historical investment results to prospective clients. questions.question:
According to the Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS), which of the following is not a part of the verification process? Testing whether the:

  1. verification is undertaken by the compliance department in the absence of a third party.
  2. firm’s processes and procedures are designed to calculate results in compliance with GIPS standards.
  3. firm has implemented policies and procedures compliant with all the composite maintenance requirements.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct. Verification tests whether the investment firm has complied with all the composite construction requirements of GIPS on a firm-wide basis, and whether the firm’s processes and procedures are designed to calculate and present performance results in compliance with the GIPS standards. Verification must be performed by an independent third party. A firm cannot perform its own verification. Incorrect. Verification tests whether the investment firm’s processes and procedures are designed to calculate and present performance results in compliance with the GIPS standards. Incorrect. Verification tests whether the investment firm has implemented policies and procedures in compliance with all the composite maintenance requirements of the GIPS standards on a firm-wide basis. Solution

  1. Correct. Verification tests whether the investment firm has complied with all the composite construction requirements of GIPS on a firm-wide basis, and whether the firm’s processes and procedures are designed to calculate and present performance results in compliance with the GIPS standards. Verification must be performed by an independent third party. A firm cannot perform its own verification.

  2. Incorrect. Verification tests whether the investment firm’s processes and procedures are designed to calculate and present performance results in compliance with the GIPS standards.
